channel.name: How to test event is emitted?

messages.content: Interesting.. you can fetch events via `fetchEvents` and then manually check for then, but I would be curious to know what the `expectEvents` method does in Solidity?
I'm sorry, it's a js lib of OpenZeppelin,  not Solidity: https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/openzeppelin-test-helpers/blob/master/src/expectEvent.js

embeds.title: openzeppelin-test-helpers/expectEvent.js at master · OpenZeppelin/o...
embeds.description: Assertion library for Ethereum smart contract testing - openzeppelin-test-helpers/expectEvent.js at master · OpenZeppelin/openzeppelin-test-helpers

messages.content: here is how you test it: https://github.com/OpenZeppelin/openzeppelin-contracts/blob/3f610ebc25480bf6145e519c96e2f809996db8ed/test/token/ERC20/ERC20.behavior.js#L64

embeds.title: openzeppelin-contracts/ERC20.behavior.js at 3f610ebc25480bf6145e519...
embeds.description: OpenZeppelin Contracts is a library for secure smart contract development. - openzeppelin-contracts/ERC20.behavior.js at 3f610ebc25480bf6145e519c96e2f809996db8ed · OpenZeppelin/openzeppelin-contracts

messages.content: yes you do - it should be part of each account update, so you can filter for it manually as well
but then you dont know if the event really got emitted on-chain, because it could always be the case your tx didnt succeed
I will check that, will come back when I solve it
I guess fetchEvents is nicer, just to make sure the event is really emitted onChain

See this comment https://github.com/o1-labs/snarkyjs/blob/21b1b41845304becf37a234e2ac39e89d7c2e63d/src/lib/fetch.ts#L667 - they are delayed by a block but only if multiple blocks at the chain tip. So realistically you'll need to wait for a block for this to be reliably returned.

embeds.title: snarkyjs/fetch.ts at 21b1b41845304becf37a234e2ac39e89d7c2e63d · o1-...
embeds.description: TypeScript framework for zk-SNARKs and zkApps. Contribute to o1-labs/snarkyjs development by creating an account on GitHub.

messages.content: One effective approach is to implement an event subscriber, which eliminates the need to fetch information. Instead, you can simply subscribe to an event and have it displayed as soon as it occurs. This can greatly improve the user experience by providing real-time updates without the need for manual refreshes or constant polling.
Hey @IaM [ZK] <DEV> has this issue been solved?
No but it’s ok you can close it.
Thats ok if it's not resolved. Lets leave it open so that when a solution has been found then we can close it 🙂
Solution has been given by Florian, so this is resolved
you can either fetchEvents on the zkApp, or browse through the account updates in your tx to find the events
